newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egyptian shares rise to 17-month high.
newsitem.headline: Egyptian shares rise to 17-month high.

text.p: Egyptian share prices kept up a record-breaking streak on Wednesday, hitting a 17-month high in busy trading, brokers said.
The Capital Market Authority (CMA) all-share index closed 0.09 points up at 234.98 in turnover of 29.40 million pounds ($8.65 million). It is the highest level since early April 1995.
Amriyah Cement was the market leader, with shares worth 7.19 million pounds traded. The share ended unchanged at 55.00 pounds.
Medinet Nasr Housing and Development ranked second with shares worth 4.31 million pounds trading. The share rose 1.40 pounds at a close to 115.50 pounds.
Among popular cement companies, Egyptian Tora Portland Cement increased 0.05 pounds to 55.55 pounds. Shares worth 407,907 pounds changed hands.
The government said it would offer 30 percent of the company for sale, in addition to the 32.5 percent it sold earlier.
Suez Cement witnessed heavy demand, but its share ended 0.05 pound lower at 41.90 pounds.
The company said on Wednesday its net pre-tax profits increased 3.42 percent to 151.02 million pounds in the first half of 1996, from 145.79 million in the same period of 1995.

Kafr el-Zayat Pesticides and Chemicals made a big jump with its share rising 4.35 percent, or 2.00 pounds, to finish at 48.00 pounds. Shares in the company were 100 times oversubscibed in a recent flotation.
The CMA index for openly traded firms rose to 344.07 points from 339.84 on Tuesday and the index for rarely traded "closed" firms went up to 160.71 points from 160.65.
Gaining stocks equalled losers at 14 to 14 while another 27 firms were traded but ended unchanged.
